results: – Another day of anti-government protests in Egypt has turned violent, with police using tear gas and water cannons to try to disperse demonstrators in Cairo and elsewhere, reports CNN. At least five people have been killed and more than 200 injured in the biggest demonstrations in years. The protests are being closely watched by the Obama administration, which warned Arab leaders two weeks ago that if they didn't address the " desperation, poverty, and lack of political freedoms in their countries and build a better future for their people, their regimes would sink into the sand," writes Elise Labott. "It puts the United States in the unenviable position of wanting and needing to support those yearnings at the same time the regimes they have long relied on for security in the region are the targets. The United States was completely caught off guard and largely absent from the scene in Tunisia."

– Protesters took to the streets of Cairo for a second straight day today, scuffling with Egyptian security forces who fired tear gas and rubber bullets in an attempt to disperse them, CNN reports. At least two people were killed in the latest unrest, including a Chicago teenager who was hit in the head by a thrown rock during a performance at President Obama's inauguration. "I really don't care who's the president," a friend of the 17-year-old protester tells Fox News. "Two men charged in death of Chicago teen who performed in inauguration event."

– Hosni Mubarak asked for his government’s resignation in a televised address this morning, and said he would form a new government with “clear and specific responsibilities” to address protesters’ demands, CNN reports. Mubarak also said he would not run for re-election next year, according to a translation of his remarks picked up by al-Jazeera. The announcement came as thousands of protesters again took to the streets in Egypt. Click here for more on the unrest in Egypt.

– Hosni Mubarak has finally made good on his promise to resign as president of Egypt, reports CNN. He handed over power to his vice president, Omar Suleiman, but did not step down as president. Mubarak did, however, promise to address the nation later today. The developments come as the death toll in days of protests rose to at least 38, reports al-Jazeera. Click here for more.

– Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak opened the door to talks with his opponents today, acknowledging in a state-run TV address that the nation’s current stage “requires us to reorganize the country’s priorities in a way that acknowledges the legitimate demands of the people.” Mubarak also called for a “wide range of dialogue” with all political parties, according to a transcript picked up by CNN. Mubarak appointed former Air Force Lt. Gen. Ahmed Shafiq as his new prime minister today. He also appointed controversial intelligence chief Omar Suleiman as his new vice president.

– It's that time of the year again, when we take a look back at some of the best movies and TV shows of the last quarter-century. Here's a look at some of the more notable winners and losers of the Golden Globes, as voted on by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences: ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ;

– Algeria's President Abdelaziz Bouteflika will lift a state of emergency that has been in place for nearly 20 years, the state news agency announced today. The move is one of several demanded by demonstrators in recent protests against the government, which imposed the emergency decree in a crackdown against Islamic political parties in 1992. The clampdown triggered an Islamist insurgency that left more than 100,000 dead, according to human rights groups. The fiery, bloody clashes between demonstrators in Cairo—with soldiers watching with seeming indifference—is an apparent maneuver by the Egyptian military to raise popular support for their intervention and the old guard police state, analysts say. – Add this to the list of things that went wrong during Christina Aguilera’s Super Bowl performance: She mixed up the fourth line of her song, “O say can you see, by the dawn’s early light, What so proudly we hail d at the twilight’s last gleaming, Whose broad stripes and bright stars through the perilous fight” with the first line of her song, “O’er the ramparts we watch ‘d were so perilously streaming.” Aguilera’s publicist released the following statement to CNN: “I got so lost in the moment of the song that I lost my place.” (Click for more on Aguilera’s flub.)

– Google exec Wael Ghonim, one of the leaders of the Egyptian protests, gave an emotional interview to CNN yesterday, saying he’s “ready to die” for change. “This is not about me,” he said several times. “This is about the people. This is our country.” He also said he’s not sure he’ll be able to continue his work as head of Google’s Middle East and North Africa office. CNN notes that Ghonim’s interview helped galvanize the protests, because it was the first time ordinary Egyptians heard a protest leader passionately defend the revolt, free from the vicious anti- protester propaganda of the state-controlled media. “Why did this one interview, this one person, so galvanize the protest movement?” asks Jake Tapper. “Because it was the first time ordinary Egyptians heard a protest leader passionately defend the revolt, free from the vicious anti- protester propaganda of the state-controlled media.”

– Opposition leader Mohammed ElBaradei spoke to CNN last night from Tahrir Square, declaring that “Egypt’s future is far from secure. But its present is rapturous, unbridled, and ultimately momentous.” ElBaradei called for a dialogue between the government and the protesters, and said he would meet with Mubarak, Vice President Omar Suleiman, and Foreign Minister Ahmed Aboul Gheit next week to “achieve a just and peaceful transition to a democratic, plural, plural country.” He also called for the release of “all political prisoners.” Mubarak’s sons Gamal and Alaa, along with their wives and children, were arrested today, but not charged, the AP reports. Egypt’s military council, meanwhile, issued a statement declaring that it was “committed to supporting the legitimate demands of the people,” according to CNN.
